modules.title: Module 1: Java Fundamentals
modules.description: Master the building blocks of Java: Syntax, Variables, Data Types, and Operators.

lessons.title: Hello World
lessons.theory: Java is a popular programming language, created in 1995. It is used for mobile apps, web apps, desktop apps, games, and much more. Every Java application begins with a class definition and a main method, which is the entry point of any Java code.

quiz.question: What is the entry point of a Java program?

lessons.title: Variables
lessons.theory: Variables are containers for storing data values. In Java, there are different types of variables, for example: String (text), int (integers), float (floating point numbers), char (single characters), and boolean (true/false). Variables must be declared with a specific type.

quiz.question: How do you declare a variable for storing whole numbers?

lessons.title: Data Types
lessons.theory: Data types are divided into two groups: Primitive data types (byte, short, int, long, float, double, boolean, char) which store simple values, and Non-primitive data types (String, Arrays, Classes) which refer to objects. Primitives are predefined by Java, while non-primitives are created by the programmer.

quiz.question: Which data type is used to store text?

lessons.title: Type Casting
lessons.theory: Type casting is when you assign a value of one primitive data type to another type. Widening Casting (automatically) - converting a smaller type to a larger type size. Narrowing Casting (manually) - converting a larger type to a smaller size type.

quiz.question: Which casting is done automatically?

lessons.title: Operators
lessons.theory: Operators are used to perform operations on variables and values. Java divides operators into groups: Arithmetic (+, -), Assignment (=, +=), Comparison (==, >), Logical (&&, ||), and Bitwise operators.

quiz.question: Which operator is used for multiplication?

project.title: Console Greeter
project.description: Write a program that declares variables for your name and age, and prints them to the console.

modules.title: Module 2: Control Flow
modules.description: Control the flow of your program with Conditions, Switches, and Loops.

lessons.title: If...Else
lessons.theory: Java supports logical conditions from mathematics. You can use these conditions to perform different actions for different decisions. Use 'if' to specify a block of code to be executed if a condition is true, and 'else' if it is false.

quiz.question: How do you start an if statement in Java?

lessons.title: Switch
lessons.theory: Use the switch statement to select one of many code blocks to be executed. The switch expression is evaluated once. The value of the expression is compared with the values of each case. If there is a match, the associated block of code is executed.

quiz.question: Which keyword is used to specify a default block of code in a switch statement?

lessons.title: While Loop
lessons.theory: The while loop loops through a block of code as long as a specified condition is true. It is useful when you don't know in advance how many times the loop should run.

quiz.question: What is a loop that never ends called?

lessons.title: For Loop
lessons.theory: When you know exactly how many times you want to loop through a block of code, use the for loop instead of a while loop. It consists of initialization, condition, and increment/decrement.

quiz.question: How many times will this loop run: for (int i = 0; i <= 10; i++)?

lessons.title: Break and Continue
lessons.theory: The break statement can also be used to jump out of a loop. The continue statement breaks one iteration (in the loop), if a specified condition occurs, and continues with the next iteration in the loop.

quiz.question: Which statement stops the loop completely?

project.title: Even or Odd
project.description: Write a program that checks if a number is even or odd using an if/else statement.

modules.title: Module 3: Object-Oriented Programming
modules.description: Dive into OOP: Classes, Objects, Constructors, Modifiers, and Encapsulation.

lessons.title: Classes & Objects
lessons.theory: Java is an object-oriented programming language. Everything in Java is associated with classes and objects, along with its attributes and methods. A Class is like a blueprint for creating objects. An Object is an instance of a class.

quiz.question: Which keyword is used to create an object from a class?

lessons.title: Modifiers
lessons.theory: By now, you are quite familiar with the public keyword that appears in almost all of our examples. The public keyword is an access modifier. Access modifiers set the access level for classes, attributes, methods and constructors (e.g., public, private, protected).

quiz.question: Which modifier makes an attribute unchangeable (constant)?

lessons.title: Constructors
lessons.theory: A constructor is a special method that is used to initialize objects. The constructor is called when an object of a class is created. It can be used to set initial values for object attributes.

quiz.question: What is the name of the constructor method?
options: It must be the same as the class name

lessons.title: Methods
lessons.theory: A method is a block of code which only runs when it is called. You can pass data, known as parameters, into a method. Methods are used to perform certain actions, and they are also known as functions.

quiz.question: How do you call a method named 'myMethod'?

lessons.title: Encapsulation
lessons.theory: The meaning of Encapsulation, is to make sure that 'sensitive' data is hidden from users. To achieve this, you must declare class variables/attributes as private and provide public get and set methods to access and update the value of a private variable.

quiz.question: Which keyword restricts access to a variable?

project.title: Student Class
project.description: Create a Student class with private fields for name and grade, and methods to get and set them.

modules.title: Module 4: Advanced OOP & Data Structures
modules.description: Explore Inheritance, Polymorphism, Abstraction, and basic Data Structures.

lessons.title: Inheritance
lessons.theory: In Java, it is possible to inherit attributes and methods from one class to another. We group the 'inheritance concept' into two categories: subclass (child) - the class that inherits from another class, and superclass (parent) - the class being inherited from. To inherit from a class, use the 'extends' keyword.

quiz.question: Which keyword is used for inheritance?

lessons.title: Polymorphism
lessons.theory: Polymorphism means 'many forms', and it occurs when we have many classes that are related to each other by inheritance. For example, think of a superclass called Animal that has a method called animalSound(). Subclasses of Animals could be Pigs, Cats, Dogs, Birds - And they also have their own implementation of an animal sound (the pig oinks, the cat meows, etc.)

quiz.question: What is polymorphism?
options: A way to create private variables
The ability of an object to take on many forms

lessons.title: Interfaces
lessons.theory: Another way to achieve abstraction in Java is with interfaces. An interface is a completely 'abstract class' that is used to group related methods with empty bodies. To access the interface methods, the interface must be 'implemented' by another class with the 'implements' keyword.

quiz.question: Which keyword is used to implement an interface?

lessons.title: Enums
lessons.theory: An enum is a special 'class' that represents a group of constants (unchangeable variables, like final variables). To create an enum, use the enum keyword (instead of class or interface), and separate the constants with a comma.

quiz.question: Can you instantiate an enum with 'new'?

lessons.title: Arrays
lessons.theory: Arrays are used to store multiple values in a single variable, instead of declaring separate variables for each value. To declare an array, define the variable type with square brackets. They have a fixed size.

quiz.question: How do you access the first element of an array named 'cars'?

lessons.title: ArrayList
lessons.theory: The ArrayList class is a resizable array, which can be found in the java.util package. While a standard array has a fixed size, an ArrayList can grow and shrink as needed. It provides more flexibility.

quiz.question: Which method adds an element to an ArrayList?

project.title: Vehicle Showroom
project.description: Create a Vehicle superclass and a Car subclass. Store Car objects in an ArrayList and print their details.

modules.title: Module 5: Exception Handling
modules.description: Gracefully handle runtime errors and maintain normal application flow.

lessons.title: Try...Catch
lessons.theory: When executing Java code, different errors can occur: coding errors made by the programmer, errors due to wrong input, or other unforeseeable things. The 'try' statement allows you to define a block of code to be tested for errors. The 'catch' statement allows you to define a block of code to be executed, if an error occurs in the try block.

quiz.question: Which block is used to handle the exception?

lessons.title: Finally Block
lessons.theory: The 'finally' statement lets you execute code, after try...catch, regardless of the result. This is useful for cleanup tasks, like closing files or database connections, that must happen whether an error occurred or not.

quiz.question: Does the finally block execute if no exception occurs?

lessons.title: Throw Keyword
lessons.theory: The 'throw' statement allows you to create a custom error. The throw statement is used together with an exception type. There are many exception types available in Java: ArithmeticException, FileNotFoundException, ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException, SecurityException, etc.

quiz.question: Which keyword is used to manually create an exception?

project.title: Safe Division
project.description: Write a program that divides two numbers and handles the 'ArithmeticException' when dividing by zero.

modules.title: Module 6: Collections Framework
modules.description: Store and manipulate groups of objects.

lessons.title: HashMap
lessons.theory: A HashMap store items in 'key/value' pairs, and you can access them by an index of another type (e.g. a String). One object is used as a key (index) to another object (value).

quiz.question: Which method is used to add items to a HashMap?

lessons.title: HashSet
lessons.theory: A HashSet is a collection of items where every item is unique, and it is found in the java.util package.

quiz.question: Does a HashSet allow duplicate values?

project.title: Phonebook
project.description: Create a Phonebook using a HashMap where keys are names and values are phone numbers.

lessons.title: Java Threads
lessons.theory: Threads allows a program to operate more efficiently by doing multiple things at the same time. Threads can be created by extending the Thread class and overriding its run() method.

quiz.question: Which method starts a thread?

lessons.title: Lambda Expressions
lessons.theory: A lambda expression is a short block of code which takes in parameters and returns a value. They are similar to methods, but they do not need a name and they can be implemented right in the body of a method.

quiz.question: Lambda expressions were introduced in which Java version?

project.title: Threaded Counter
project.description: Create a program that uses a thread to count down from 10 while the main program prints 'Waiting...'.

modules.title: Module 8: File Handling
modules.description: Learn how to create, read, update, and delete files in Java.

lessons.title: Java Files
lessons.theory: The File class from the java.io package, allows us to work with files. To use the File class, create an object of the class, and specify the filename or directory name.

quiz.question: Which package contains the File class?

lessons.title: Create & Write
lessons.theory: To create a file, use the createNewFile() method. To write to a file, use the FileWriter class.

quiz.question: Which method is used to write text to a file?

project.title: Note Taker
project.description: Create a program that takes user input and saves it to a text file.

modules.title: Module 9: Date & Time
modules.description: Working with dates and times using the java.time package.

lessons.title: Java Dates
lessons.theory: Java does not have a built-in Date class, but we can import the java.time package to work with the date and time API. LocalDate represents a date (year, month, day), LocalTime represents a time (hour, minute, second, nanoseconds), LocalDateTime represents both.

quiz.question: Which class represents both date and time?

lessons.title: Formatting Dates
lessons.theory: The 'ofPattern()' method from the DateTimeFormatter class allows you to format date and time objects.

quiz.question: Which pattern displays the year as 4 digits?

project.title: Digital Clock
project.description: Display the current date and time in a specific format.

lessons.title: Java Math
lessons.theory: The Java Math class has many methods that allows you to perform mathematical tasks on numbers.

quiz.question: Which method returns the square root of a number?

lessons.title: Java Regex
lessons.theory: A regular expression is a sequence of characters that forms a search pattern. When you search for data in a text, you can use this search pattern to describe what you are searching for.

quiz.question: Which class is used to define a pattern (to be used in a search)?

lessons.title: Wrapper Classes
lessons.theory: Wrapper classes provide a way to use primitive data types (int, boolean, etc..) as objects. Sometimes you must use wrapper classes, for example when working with Collection objects, such as ArrayList, where primitive types cannot be used (the list can only store objects).

quiz.question: What is the wrapper class for 'int'?

project.title: Password Validator
project.description: Use Regex to check if a password contains at least one number and one uppercase letter.
